DOC.HEAD: Opposition Scores in Portuguese Local Elections
DOC.TEXT: The opposition Socialist Party claimed major victories in local voting Sunday with the election of its leader as mayor of Lisbon and the capture of other large cities and government strongholds. The governing, center-right Social Democrats of Prime Minister Anibal Cavaco Silva received most votes nationwide when initial results were announced, winning an estimated 40 percent of the vote, according to state RTP television. However, the loss of Lisbon, Oporto in the north, the major cities of Coimbra and Faro, and Social Democratic strongholds on Madeira and in the Azores islands were hailed as triumphs by the opposition. ``This is a clear defeat for the government and the Social Democratic Party on a national scale _ and the Lisbon result shows the capital doesn't even trust the ministries it houses,'' Socialist Party leader Jorge Sampaio told a news conference at his party headquarters. Three hours after polling stations closed, about 35 percent of the vote was reported as having gone to the Socialists, 11 percent to the conservative Democratic Social Center and 9 percent to the Communists. No vote totals were available. Sampaio won in Lisbon as candidate of an unprecedented alliance between Socialists and Communists that won from 48 to 50 percent of the city vote. His conservative opponent, Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa, admitted defeat after hearing first estimates. Shortly after initial results were announced, Socialist Party spokesman Antonio Lopes Cardoso said Sampaio would not join forces with the Communists in the next legislative elections slated for 1991. The Social Democrats had warned that a leftist victory in Lisbon could tempt the Socialists to maintain the alliance in general elections and so let the Communists into the federal government by the back door. The government has slipped in popularity since winning Portugal's first absolute majority in 1987 on the promise of free-market economic policies and rapid modernization. A consumer boom and big foreign investment have brought prosperity to some, but annual inflation of more than 12 percent has squeezed low-income budgets. Persistent rumors of high-level corruption also plagued the Social Democrats. About 8 million Portuguese were eligible to vote in elections for 55,000 local authorities. Voting in Cunha Alta in the northern region of Mangulade was postponed until Sunday, Dec. 24, after strong winds ripped roofs off houses and injured at least two people, the Portuguese news agency Lusa reported.
